elements.text: PART ONE
1: PRE-TITLES (REPRISE FROM ‘CASTLE OF FEAR’ )
(FX: THE ENGINES OF A SPACESHIP ARE OVERLOADING. BASSY RUMBLE
GROWING IN VOLUME. CIRCUITS GURGLING AND BELCHING. THE DOCTOR
PUNCHING BUTTONS, KNOTTING CABLES, RIPPING OPEN SHELL LAYERS,...)
Doctor — that sound...
(BREATHLESS, WHILST ATTEMPTING TO FIX THINGS) Yes. Atrial dysrhythmia! The ship’s engines are fibrillating!
Fibrillating?
It’s suffering a heart attack! If I can’t find some way of stabilising the sinus rhythm... the hyperspatial warp core will ignite — and the entire ship will explode!
But if it explodes — the consequences would be catastrophic —
Yes. No more planet Earth. No more solar system, for that matter. In fact, it’d take rather a large chunk out of the Milky Way.
Then hadn’t you better hurry?
(SQUEEZING INTO SMALL AREA) I’m trying, Nyssa. It’s complicated. There should be some sort of metabolic fail-safe, if only I can find — (PAIN) Ow!
NYSSA3: What’s the matter?
That bit’s hot.
How long do you think we have?
Until it explodes? Not long. A few minutes, if we’re lucky.
And if we’re unlucky?
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 3
I recommend not starting any long sentences.
NYSSA3: But what if there isn’t a ‘metabolic fail-safe’?
Ah. I was hoping you wouldn’t ask that. If I can just manage to — (REALISATION) No. No response. It’s dead! (BEAT) There’s nothing I can do. Get back to the TARDIS!
I’m not leaving you, Doctor.
Nyssa. That’s an order! It’s your only chance.
NYSSA3: Then come with me.
It’s too late... warp core ignition. It’s going to — (explode)
(FX: THE DOCTOR’S WORDS ARE CUT OFF BY A DEVASTATING EXPLOSION. WHICH TURNS INTO A WARPING, ECHOING, PHASING, AS THOUGH TIME ITSELF IS BEING RIPPED APART... TAKING US INTO THE OPENING TITLES! )
2: BED AND BREAKFAST BEDROOM
FX: CALM, SUMMERY ATMOSPHERE. BIRDSONG. A KNOCK AT THE DOOR.
(VIA DOOR) Doctor?
(WAKING) Hmm?
(VIA DOOR) Doctor Smith? Are you awake yet? Your breakfast.
(CONFUSED) My... come in. (LOUDER) Come in!
FX: DOOR OPENS. ALICE ENTERS WITH CLINKING BREAKFAST TRAY.
Still in bed, I see! Well, I won’t be keeping you. There you go — boiled egg, toast and a cup of tea. Two sugars. Just as you like it!
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 4
Er.. thanks. I’m sorry to ask, but... who are you?
Who am I?
Humour me.
Alice. Alice Withers? Ooh, it’s a beautiful day out. You couldn’t ask for a finer day.
FX: DRAWING CURTAINS, OPENING WINDOW
And you’ve brought me... breakfast.
Well, the Green Dragon is a bed and breakfast, you know! Speaking of which, you should make a start, your tea’ll be getting cold.
You called me Doctor Smith. How d’you know my, er, name?
I don’t know. You must’ve told us, I suppose!
When did I tell you?
Oh, it’s too long ago to remember. You just... told us.
(DRINKS) And how do you know how I take my tea?
How do I know? Milk, two sugars, it’s what you always have.
What I always have?
You’ve had the same breakfast all the time you’ve been here. Boiled egg, toast and —
How long have I been here?
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 5
Oh, now, let me see — you’ve been staying with us for.. well, about as long as I can remember. Come to think of it, I can’t remember a time when you weren’t here.
But I can’t have always been here, can I?
If you say so, Doctor Smith. I’1ll be leaving you now, while you get yourself dressed —
Wait. One last thing. Silly question, but — where am I?
Are you having fun? Only I’m not really in the mood.
No. No. I’m just a trifle.. disorientated, that’s all.
A bad dream?
Yes, that’s it, a very bad dream. So where am I?
Stockbridge village, of course.
Stockbridge. Yes. (SIGH) It would have to be.
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 6
3: BED AND BREAKFAST DINING ROOM
(FX: CREAKING STAIRS. DOOR OPENS. CLOCK TICKING. NEWSPAPERS BEING TIDIED. RADIO PLAYING CLASSICAL MUSIC.)
Ah, Doctor. Feeling better? Alice mentioned you weren’t quite yourself this morning.
Yes.. (BEAT) Sorry, who do you think I am?
(AMUSED) Who do I think you are?
When I am myself.
You're the Doctor. Doctor John Smith. The village Doctor.
(FX: ALICE ENTERS FROM KITCHEN — DOOR SWINGING SHUT. TIDYING, DUSTING. )
Ah, up and about I see. Breakfast alright, was it?
Yes, just as I like it.. Alice, wasn’t it? So this would be your... husband? Mr Withers?
Harold.
You couldn’t remind me — when did I first come to stay with you?
What?
When did you meet me for the first time? When did I arrive?
I don’t remember you ever arriving, do you Alice?
No.
You don’t remember?
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 7
No, it’s just.. you’ve always been here.
But there must have been a time before, when I wasn’t here.
No, don’t think so.
What, so I was here yesterday?
Yes.
And the day before that?
Yes.
And the day before that?
Yes.
And the year before that? And the year before that?
What you getting at, Doctor?
Harold, how long have you been running this bed and breakfast?
Ooh, must be getting on for thirty years now.
At least, if not more. Ever since we were married.
(FX: WE GET A SPOOKY, ECHOEY, ACROSS-STEREO BURST OF SCENE 7.
HAROLD: I’ll never forget it, for as long as I live!)
So I was your guest, thirty years ago?
Don’t know. Suppose you must’ve been.
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002)
Page 8
But how old would that make me? Fifty? Do I look fifty to you? Tell me — Alice — what happened yesterday? What did I do?
What did you do?
Can’t you remember?
I’m asking a question. Please!
Well, I made you breakfast, boiled egg, cup of tea, just as you like it.
And then?
Then you came downstairs, and we had a little chat,
the one we’re having now, come to think of it...
And after that? What did I do?
I don’t know. You must’ve gone out, I suppose.
two sugars,
much like
But you’re not sure? Interesting. One other thing. Has anyone else arrived in Stockbridge? Recently, I mean. In the last
couple of days.
Arrived?
Yes. A stranger in the village. Someone you haven’t met before?
We don’t really get many strangers in this village,
No. In fact, we don’t get any.
No-one? No-one at all?
No. At least, not —
Doctor.
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 9
. aS far as you can remember. Yes. well, if you’1ll excuse me, I have to find someone.
FX: DOOR OPENS TO THE OUTSIDE.
Yes. Oh, I remember now! Yesterday.
What?
After you came down, after breakfast, we had a little chat... and then you left because you had to go and find someone, that was it.
Just like today?
Yes. Yes... exactly like today.
4: VILLAGE GREEN
(FX: FOOTSTEPS ON GRAVEL. GATE. FOOTSTEPS. BIRDSONG. DUCKS. CHURCH BELLS AND SINGING — ‘THERE IS A GREEN HILL FAR AWAY’.)
(TO HIMSELF)

Stockbridge! The one place in the universe where nothing ever changes. The village green, St Justinian’s church and the duck pond... all present and correct. J Grubb’s General Store. The Green Dragon. The Redfern Inn. And beyond, Wells Wood and the rolling English countryside. Bright sunshine, clear blue skies and a gentle summer breeze. With nothing to break the tranquillity...
FX: BICYCLE BELLS RUNG URGENTLY.
Excuse me! Out the way! Woah-aah!
FX: BICYCLE BRAKES SUDDENLY. SKID. SPLASH. INDIGNANT DUCKS.
(HAVING FALLEN) Ow!
Doctor!
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 10
(TO HIMSELF, ACHING) And of course the young maid cycling to school...
Are you alright? Let me help you.
I’m fine. One or two bruises, but I’1l survive.
(FX: THE DOCTOR EXTRACTS HIMSELF FROM THE DUCK POND, DRIPPING
I’m sorry, I didn’t see you, the sun was in my eyes, and the wall moved —
Don’t mention it. Maybe you should get those brakes seen to, Miss — I’m sorry, would you mind telling me your name?
My name?
I know, you already know me, I already know you, but for the sake of argument?
Jane. Jane Potter.
(FX: A BRIEF, SPOOKY, PAN-ACROSS-STEREO BURST OF SCENE 47.
Leave me alone, I don’t want to see you any more... Let go, you’re hurting me...)
(LAUGHS) Did you bang your head?
No. It’s just... I’m not quite sure how I got here.
In the duck pond?
No, in Stockbridge. No, don’t tell me. I’ve been here for as long as you can remember.
Well, yes!
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 11
Trouble is, I don’t. Remember, that is. The last thing I remember is... it doesn’t matter. You wouldn’t happen to have seen a friend of mine? Young girl, about your age —
Would that be Miss Nyssa, by any chance?
(DISCONCERTED) Yes, it would. Do you know her?
Of course. I’ve known her for, well, for about as long as I can remember.
FX: BICYCLE RIGHTED AND MOUNTED. BELL JANGLES.
I should have guessed. Where is she?
Probably the post office. That’d be the first place I’d look. Now, I’m sorry, but I’ve got to dash —
Yes, of course. I’1l1 um.. see you again, Jane.
Hopefully next time I’1ll see you first! Bye bye, Doctor!
FX: JANE CYCLES AWAY.
Post office. Right...!
FX: DOCTOR WALKS AWAY, DAMPLY. THEN A VOICE, CLOSE-BY...
(DELIGHTED) It can’t be.. it is! The enigmatic Doctor! So you’ve returned at last!
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 12
5. POST OFFICE
(FX: DOOR OPENS, CAUSING BELL TO JINGLE. FOOTSTEPS ENTER. DOOR CLOSES WITH A JINGLE)
Hello? Shop? It’s the Doctor. I’m looking for —
FX: INTERIOR DOOR OPENS.
NYSSA3: Doctor!
Nyssa! There you are.
What happened to you? It's not raining outside, so why are you (soaking) -
(EMBARRASSED) Don't ask. What about you?
I’m fine. Fine. But I’ve been having a very strange morning.
You’re not the only one.
I woke up, in a room upstairs. None of my clothes were here, so I had to put on this... attire. And, when I came downstairs, people kept wandering in expecting me to sell them stamps!
(AMUSED) Did they?
They seem to think I’m some sort of ‘postmistress’.
Indeed. They seem to think I’m some sort of Doctor.
Everyone was acting as though they already knew me. As if I’d been an inhabitant in this settlement for years.
But you haven’t, have you? What’s the last thing you remember?
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 13
I was with you, the engines of the Rutan ship were ‘fibrillating’. And then there was an explosion... and after that, nothing, until I woke up here.
Yes. The same for me.
But what happened? I’m not a ‘postmistress’!
No. It’s as if someone has found roles for us. Trying to make us fit into the village...
The village? Where are we?
Don’t you recognise it? We’ve been here before.
FX: DOOR OPENS WITH A BELL JANGLE, THEY MOVE OUTSIDE.
Stockbridge! It’s just as it was, when I met Andrew. It hasn’t changed a bit! Do you think he might still be here, somewhere?
Not sure. Depends on the year.
And what year is it?
By the look of those cars, the double-glazing, I’d say... early twenty-first century?
Very scientific!
Well, there’s only one to be really sure — go to the same place everyone else goes if they want to find something out...
NYSSA3: Which is?
The local pub — The Redfern Inn. Come on, best foot forward...!
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 14
6. PUB
FX: TIDYING UP — MOVING CHAIRS OFF TABLES, WIPING SURFACES.
Andrew Harper? Doesn’t ring any bells, I’m afraid.
He used to live here a few years ago. Maybe he moved away?
Don’t think so, love. Never been an Andrew Harper in Stockbridge.
But he used to come here, I’m sure of it... you can’t have forgotten him!
Not a name I know. Sorry, love.
Mister... er...
Dudley. Dudley Jackson.
(FX: ANOTHER SPOOKY BURST. FROM SCENE 24. DUDLEY: It was an accident. One minute she was standing there, the next the edge just gave way — )
You wouldn’t be able to tell us what year it is, would you?
What year?
It’s the oddest thing, but when I woke up this morning I didn’t know what day it was.
Well, it’s the fourth of August, two thousand and nine —
(FX: AS HE SAYS THIS, WE HEAR ECHOES OF HIM SAYING OTHER DATES:
the ninth of June, nineteen sixty-four — / the twenty- first of August, nineteen eighty-one — / the eighteenth of July, nineteen fifty — )
And that’s the year? You’re sure?
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 15
As sure as I’m standing here, talking to you now.
Thank you, Mr... Jackson, you’ve been most helpful...
7: VILLAGE GREEN
FX: PUB DOOR CLOSES. DOCTOR AND NYSSA WALKING HURRIEDLY.
Doctor! When you asked him what year it is, he said —
Yes, Nyssa, I heard it too. Look around you, notice anything different?
No, I —
The cars. That’s a Morris Traveller. That’s a Mini Cooper...
NYSSA3: So?
No double glazing. No satellite dishes. This isn’t two thousand and nine.
NYSSA3: Then when — when is it?
The sixties? Seventies? Who can tell? (SEES SOMEONE) Hello!
(CALLING OUT) Doctor Smith...! So you found Miss Nyssa, then?
Jane. You’re looking different — and very... charming. I like your hat!
Well, you’ve got to make a bit of an effort, haven’t you? For a wedding.
A wedding?
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 16
You must be coming, everyone in the village is invited!
Yes, of course. Wouldn’t miss it for the world, would we, Nyssa? St Justinian’s, is it?
Of course. Should hurry, though, the service is at twelve...
(SOTTO) Doctor. Her clothes... they’re from a different time period.
(SOTTO) Indeed. I’m no expert, but nineteen-fifties, I'd say...
(SOTTO) And something else. It can’t be twelve o’clock yet — it’s barely an hour since I woke up!
(SOTTO) Yes. I was wondering if you’d notice that. Not to mention the fact that my trousers still haven’t dried —
Jane, wasn’t it?
Yes?
(FX: A BRIEF SPOOKY BURST OF SCENE 24: JANE: The problem went away. And I know I should feel sad about it, but I don’t. I’m
glad. )
It may seem an odd question, but what day is this?
You’re right. It is an odd question. Don’t you know?
I’m not sure of the exact date, is it the fourth, fifth...?
It’s the sixteenth. Of June. Nineteen fifty-two.
(FX: AS WITH DUDLEY, WE HEAR HER STATING OTHER DATES AS WELL.
It’s the eighth. Of July. Nineteen ninety-six / It’s the
thirtieth of August. Nineteen seventy / It’s the twelfth of June. Ninety eighty-four. )
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 17
NYSSA3: Doctor... she —
I know. Something very strange is happening here.. something to do with time.
FX: CHURCH BELLS. A GATE IS OPENED. A CHEER. CHURCH DOOR.
Speaking of which, I think we’ve missed the service — oh my. I don’t believe it!
FX: VILLAGERS EMERGING FROM CHURCH. LAUGHTER. CHURCH BELLS.
NYSSA3: What is it?
The bride and groom.
What about them? They seem perfectly ordinary to me —
It’s Harold and Alice. From the Green Dragon.
NYSSA3: So?
I met them, earlier today. But they were in their fifties, they’d been married for thirty years...
But that couple — they can’t be more than twenty years old...
(FX: CROWD HUBBUB, CHATTING. HAROLD AND ALICE DON’T SOUND YOUNGER, BUT THERE MIGHT BE A SLIGHT TREATMENT ON THE VOCALS. )
Ah, Doctor Smith, Miss Nyssa. Knew you’d make it in the end!
Congratulations, Harold. And Alice. Sorry about missing the, ah, happy occasion — you know how it is, unavoidably detained!
The happiest man in all the world, she’s made me, Doctor. I’1l never forget it, for as long as I live!
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 18
Me neither. Gawd, I felt so nervous in there, all those eyes staring at me, I thought I was going to be sick, but now it’s done, I don’t feel so bad after all.
I should hope not!
No, I mean... oh, you know what I mean. Mister Withers.
Mrs Withers.
(WARNING) Doctor —
Yes, Nyssa, what?
The other side of the village.
What? I expect somebody’s having a bonfire, that’s all. A bit antisocial for midsummer, perhaps, but nothing to — oh no. That’s no bonfire...
That’s the school. The village school... it’s on fire!
(FX: WE SUDDENLY WHOOSH! INTO A FLASHBACK, ‘LOST’-STYLE. THIS IS COMBINED WITH A CACOPHONY OF VOICES, NOISES FROM OTHER
SCENES. IT’S AS IF THE LISTENER IS BEING WRENCHED THROUGH TIME. )
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 19
8: SCHOOL
(FX: THE SCHOOL IS BURNING. THERE’S COUGHING. SCREAMING, CRYING. )
Anyone in there?
I don’t know, I —
You’re the schoolmistress. Is there anyone in there?
There shouldn’t be, I keep it locked up. Someone must’ve broken in.. Dudley, what are you doing?
There’s a boy in there! I saw him. At the window, waving he was.
You can’t go in there — you’1l get killed.
Yeah but, you know me, I’m a coward, right?
FX: CRASH OF DOORS. WHOOSH OF FLAME. SCREAMS AND COMMOTION.
Dudley! Come back — I...
What’s got into him?
He says he saw someone in there. A boy...
Harold. Where’s our Philip?
I don’t know, I thought he was out playing with his friends — cowboys and indians, he was wearing his cowboy hat, last I saw.
I told you to keep an eye on him! I told you!
He’s probably just hiding, playing a game —
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 20
FX: DOORS SPLINTERING.
Dudley — are you alright — !
(COUGHING) Somebody, get the Doctor. Get the Doctor...
Oh no. It’s our Philip. Philip!
Phil boy, speak to your dad — ah, Doctor Smith! You’re here!
Okay, everyone, stand back, please, we need some air.
He was like this when I found him, Doctor — just lying there —
Doctor, what —
I’m doing my best, Nyssa. Come on... come on... breathe for me, breathe!
(FX: THE DOCTOR PERFORMS RESUSCITATION — THUMPING BOY’S CHEST, BLOWING INTO HIS MOUTH, LISTENING FOR HEARTBEAT, THEN REPEATING — I.E. ‘ONE, TWO’ — BLOWS, LISTENS, ‘ONE, TWO’ — BLOWS, LISTENS. )
Come on, Philip — stay with us, lad —
He must’ve been playing, cowboys and indians.
(BREATHLESS ) (GIVING UP) No. It’s no good. I’m sorry. I’m very sorry, but he’s — (dead)
(FX: WE WHOOSH! OUT OF FLASHBACK — VERY LOUD, SUDDEN, MID-WORD, WITH THE SAME FEW SECONDS OF MIXED-UP VILLAGERS’ VOICES, TO:)
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 21
9: CHURCHYARD
(FX: CHURCH BELLS TOLLING. FUNEREAL ATMOSPHERE. THE FOLLOWING DIALOGUE FADES AS WE MOVE AWAY WITH THE DOCTOR AND NYSSA:
(IN BACKGROUND ONLY)

Forasmuch as it hath pleased Almighty God of his great mercy to take unto himself the soul of our dear brother here departed, we therefore commit his body to the ground; earth to earth, ashes to ashes, dust to dust; in sure and certain hope of the Resurrection to eternal life, through our Lord Jesus Christ —
FX: DOCTOR AND NYSSA TALK OVER THS, WALKING FROM THE SERVICE.
(SOTTO) Doctor — did you —
The fire at the village school? Yes.
It’s as if we were really there. A part of events.
I think we were really there.
I don’t understand.
This funeral, Nyssa... who’s it for?
For the young boy, Philip. His parents, Harold and Alice were standing by the grave... (REALISATION) Where’s Harold? He was here.
It’s his funeral.
But a few minutes ago... it was his wedding day!
‘A day in the life’..? Look again now.
I don’t see... They’ve gone. Everyone’s gone! The grave, it’s been filled in!
FX: A CHURCH BELL TOLLS. ROOKS CAW. THE VICAR HAS ALSO GONE.
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 22
Come on. There’s something I want to check.
NYSSA3: What?
The gravestone. I thought so. Read the inscription.
(READS) ‘In memory of... Harold Withers, Alice Withers and their loving son Philip.’
And that one.
‘Here lies.. Jane Potter.’ ‘Dudley Jackson.’ They’re dead, Doctor. They’re all dead!
Anything else strike you as odd?
I’m not familiar with this planet’s burial traditions, Doctor —
No dates. None of the gravestones have dates!
What does that mean?
Well, either the stonemason was particularly careless, or it means... all these people have died but nobody knows when.
NYSSA3: Doctor. Was that there before?
What?
On the corner of the village green...
The TARDIS! Now we’ll start getting some answers — !
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 23
10: VILLAGE GREEN
FX: WE’RE NEAR THE DUCKPOND AGAIN. A BREEZE IS BLOWING.
Do you have the key? (SHIVERS) Is it me, or is it getting cold, all of a sudden?
Should have it somewhere... (SURPRISE) Hello. It’s not locked.
FX: AS HE SAYS THIS, THE DOOR CREAKS OPEN.
The console room... where is it? This is just...
.the inside of an ordinary Police Telephone Box! One desk, one stool, one electric heater. And one telephone, of course.
NYSSA3: What could have done this to the TARDIS?
We can’t be sure this is the TARDIS. For all we know, it might be the genuine article...
FX: THE DOCTOR TRIES TELEPHONE. RATTLES RECEIVER. DIAL TONE.
3: Don’t tell me — there’s no connection.
No. There is. Hmmm, now let’s see —
(FX: DIALS. IT’S AN OLD-FASHIONED ROTARY DIAL — CLICK CLIIICK CLIIICK. 100.)
It’s ringing.
(FX: IT RINGS. ONCE, TWICE. A DISTANT VOICE ANSWERS,
(VIA PHONE) Hello?
Ah. I wonder if you can help me. I’d like to be put through —
It’s me.
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 24
Sorry, what?
It’s me. The voice at the other end of the phone. It’s me!
Yes, I realise that but... wait. I recognise that voice!
It’s happening just as before. Time is winding back on itself —
Winding back on itself?
FX: THE PERSON AT THE OTHER END HANGS UP.
Doctor, what is it? Who did you speak to?
Who indeed... I’m afraid they weren’t terribly (helpful) —
(FX: THE DOCTOR IS INTERRUPTED BY THE PHONE RINGING. ONCE, TWICE. )
NYSSA3: Don’t answer it.
I don’t think I have any choice...
FX: HE PICKS UP THE PHONE.
Hello?
FX: AND WE HAVE THE SECOND HALF OF THE PREVIOUS CONVERSATION...
(VIA PHONE) Ah. I wonder if you can help me. I’d like to be put through —
(REALISING) It’s me.
Sorry, what?
NYSSA3: Who is it?
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 25
It’s me. The voice at the other end of the phone. It’s me!
Yes, I realise that but... wait. I recognise that voice!
It’s happening just as before. Time is winding back on itself.
Winding back on itself?
FX: THE DOCTOR HANGS UP. THEY EMERGE FROM THE POLICE BOX.
Somebody doesn’t want us calling the outside world.
Who?
I don’t know. But it’s something to do with this place, the village...
Doctor, should the sun be setting dark so soon? The clouds, it’s as if they’re on fire —
Beautiful, isn’t it? But you’re right. Time’s moving too quickly...
Like the couple we saw, getting married and being buried on the
same day...
Yes. The villagers seem to be a part this... they might not even be aware there’s anything amiss...
Oh no, Doctor. I think you’ll find we’re all-too aware!
FX: MAX IS NEARBY. DOCTOR AND NYSSA REACT.
Good grief, has no-one ever told — Max! Maxwell Edison! What are you doing here?
I’ve been observing you, following you, photographing you. Ever since you arrived!
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 26
Hence the, ah, binoculars — and camera with telephoto lens. Why didn’t you say hello?
I had to make sure it was you. In my experience, you can never be too sure. Strange forces have been afoot in Stockbridge, Doctor. Strange and... mysterious forces.
(PISS-TAKING) Strange and mysterious?
Doctor, do you know this... person?
I do. Nyssa, meet Max. A blast from my past — or possibly from my future. (ASIDE) He’s what you might call a flying saucer nut. In the, ah, nicest possible way!
(UNCONVINCED) I see.
He stumbled into the TARDIS once... The night that stars fell on Stockbridge...
FX: A FLASHBACK. A NOSTALGIC WALK-DOWN-MEMORY-LANE EFFECT.
11. TARDIS CONSOLE ROOM
FX: THE TARDIS DOORS ARE CLOSING AS SOMEONE STAGGERS IN.
Oh! My! Good! Ness!
Ah... I wouldn’t touch that if I were you...
(COUGHS) Er... Welcome, my friend — welcome to Earth! I am Earth ambassador Edison, and I take great pleasure in —
What are you doing here?
I tracked your craft to Earth with my ‘bio-kinetic energising ray’...
THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 27
FX: WE LEAVE THE FLASHBACK MOMENTARILY.
(SOTTO) (INCREDULOUS) A bio-kinetic energising ray?
(SOTTO) Yes. Well, it was just an empty box with a few loose wires... but
it turned out he really had detected an alien spacecraft...
FX: TAKING US TO ANOTHER FLASHBACK:
12. ALIEN SPACESHIP
FX: IT’S AN ECHOEY, CLANGY, SINISTER PLACE.

LIZZIE: A village that mysteriously vanished off the face of the planet sixty years ago. You may have heard of it. It’s called Stockbridge.
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 64
DOCTOR WHO: 38. INSIDE MANOR
DOCTOR: Supposing, for the sake of argument, you are my future self... what happens to me?
LADY: You remain in Stockbridge forever.
DOCTOR: Are you sure? Forever’s an awfully long time...
LORD: The Lady Nyssa and I have ruled over Stockbridge for countless millennia.
LADY: We stopped keeping track after the first ten thousand centuries.
DOCTOR: (WHISTLES) That long, eh? I’m surprised you still remember who you are!
LORD: (REMEMBERING) I remember... I was a Lord, once. Of Time. I gave my name as ‘the Doctor’, but that wasn’t my real name. My real name was... it was...
DOCTOR: (AMUSED, TEASING) You’ve forgotten!
LORD: It has been so long since I have had cause to think of it. But I remember, before I came to Stockbridge. I had a home. ‘Gallverey’. Then I fled, to voyage across the gulfs of time. So many worlds I saw, so many lives I lived. Back... when I was you.
DOCTOR: And the Lady Nyssa?
LADY: I.. I know I was a Lady. Of Traken. My family died, my home world died. But it all feels like it happened in another life. Like.. a half-remembered childhood dream.
DOCTOR: So you don’t remember Tegan? Or Adric? The Master? The Cybermen?
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 65
LADY: The words are unfamiliar. The time before the village... it all seems so distant now.
DOCTOR: And what about this manor house of yours, hmmm?
DOCTOR: (FX: A DOOR IS UNBOLTED AND OPENED. THEY MOVE INTO A NEW AREA. TRICKLING WATER. FLAGSTONES. A TRANQUIL, SUMMERY ATMOSPHERE. )
LORD: Haven’t you guessed yet? Look, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Yes, a conservatory. Very pleasant. Could do with a spot of pruning. What about it?
LORD: This is the most ancient part of Stockbridge Manor. The first part to be built.
LADY: The first part we constructed.
DOCTOR: Constructed? You built this place between you?
LADY: Over the millennia. Stone by stone.
DOCTOR: Well, I’m impressed at your workmanship, but I still don’t see...
LORD: Look again, Doctor.
DOCTOR: What am I looking for? Vines... ivy.. moss, an ornamental fountain, statues and some sort of — oh my word. But that’s impossible... what are they doing here?
LADY: Impossible?
DOCTOR: Warp core engines! Or what’s left of them. But that means...
LORD: Yes, Doctor?
DOCTOR: That means... the manor house. You’ve built it on the remains of the Rutan ship!
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 66
DOCTOR WHO: 39. PIG BASE.
LIZZIE: You don’t mind if I.., do you? (INHALES) Dreadful habit. So your gentlemen friend, this ‘Doctor’... he’s still in Stockbridge?
LIZZIE: NYSSA3: As far as I know.
LIZZIE: And you don’t know how you ended up there?
NYSSA: No. Now perhaps you could answer my questions?
LIZZIE: Fire away.
NYSSA: You said the village ‘mysteriously vanished’. What precisely do you mean?
LIZZIE: One minute it was there, the next it... wasn’t. Happened sometime around the end of World War Two. It was all hushed-up, they Said it'd been destroyed by a V-2.
LIZZIE: NYSSA3: But it hadn’t?
LIZZIE: If it had, you’d expect there to be a vast smoking crater, right? Witnesses? Survivors? Instead, there was nothing. It’s not just that the village wasn’t there. It was as if a big circle on the map had been cut away — and space had been folded in around it.
LIZZIE: NYSSA3: But that’s ridiculous!
LIZZIE: Ridiculous or not, you’d walk towards the point on the map where Stockbridge should be... and pass straight through to the other side. The village hadn’t been blown up by a Jerry bomb. It had been reduced to a singularity.
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 67
DOCTOR WHO: 40. INSIDE MANOR CONSERVATORY
DOCTOR: The engines... they’re just as they were before. A little rusty, but essentially intact.
LORD: 'Before...?’
DOCTOR: Before the explosion... But they didn’t explode, did they? I’m beginning to understand. The warp core didn’t ignite... because I'd activated the fail-safe!
DOCTOR: DOCTOR There should be some sort of metabolic fail-safe, if only I can find...
LADY: You saved the Earth from destruction, Doctor. In so doing, you created this place.
DOCTOR: Of course! The engines would have been instantly enclosed within a stasis field. Allowing the pilot to make the necessary repairs... or retreat to a place of safety.
LORD: Go on.
DOCTOR: But rather than enclose just the engines, the bubble inflated! Expanding to take in the village, its inhabitants... and everything that’s happened here in the past sixty years!
LADY: At last you comprehend.
LORD: (MOCKING) So you see, it’s you, Doctor. You are the one who trapped us here for all eternity. It was all because of you!
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 68
DOCTOR WHO: 41. PIG BASE
NYSSA: So, if it was reduced to a singularity, how did you locate it?
LIZZIE: It all kicked off about a year ago. People in the area reported seeing hallucinations. They’d catch sight of a village shimmering in the distance, as though it was made of mist. Only for a second, but it was there. Like Brigadoon.
NYSSA: Like what?
LIZZIE: ‘Brigadoon’. The old musical, you know? With Gene Kelly and Val Johnson.
NYSSA: I’m sorry, I’m not familiar with the reference.
LIZZIE: It’s not important. Anyway, soon it wasn’t just the village that people saw. About a month ago, they began to see the inhabitants too! That’s when the P I G received the summons. The manifestations tend to be concentrated around Well’s Wood, on the outskirts of where the village would’ve been — on the edge of the missing circle.
NYSSA: I’m sorry — the ‘manifestations’?
LIZZIE: We don’t like to call them ghosts. It’s a bit embarrassing.
LIZZIE: 42. INSIDE MANOR
DOCTOR: That’s what you’ve been doing? Ruling over Stockbridge? Tell me, what are the hours like? If I’m going to be taking over, I’d quite like to know what I’m letting myself in for.
LORD: All shall become clear, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Deferring explanations... that’s a very annoying habit. I really must stop doing it...
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 69
DOCTOR WHO: DUDLEY & MAX: My Lord, my Lady.
LADY: The stargazer.. and the Innkeeper. How considerate of you to wait.
DUDLEY: I require absolution.
MAX: And me, too... please.
LADY: And you shall have it.
DOCTOR: Absolution?
LORD: The only way the villagers can endure.
DOCTOR: Endure? I thought everyone in this village was ‘dearly departed’?
LADY: The people of Stockbridge are held, forever, as they were at the instant of their death. Suspended in the moment. Dying and yet... undying.
DOCTOR: So not so much an afterlife as a living death.
LADY: The Innkeeper first, I think. I have an... appetite for his melancholy.
LORD: Now, Doctor. Observe, how we endure...
LADY: Innkeeper, give me your hand... so I might release you from the shackles of the past —
LADY: (FX: DUDLEY SUDDENLY STARTS SCREAMING, GASPING. IN GREAT PAIN. A SUPERNATURAL WIND ROARS OUT OF NOWHERE. INCLUDING BRIEF,
LADY: INCOHERENT SNIPPETS OF DUDLEY DIALOGUE FROM OTHER SCENES. AND THEN A DISTORTED, PANNING-ACROSS-STEREO REPRISE OF SCENE 23)
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 70
JANE: Come on, jump! Water’s lovely.
DUDLEY: The bridge isn’t safe, I’m not doing it —
LADY: (DURING THE ABOVE) Ah. Such tender-hearted memories. Truly, to be savoured.. like wine!
JANE: Is this you proposing?
DUDLEY: What do you want, rings and violins? I’m asking, Yes.
LADY: (DURING THE ABOVE) Oh, such bitter-sweet remembrances. Delicious!! More! I must have more!
JANE: The problem went away. And I know I should feel sad about it, but I don’t. I’m glad.
DOCTOR: (DURING THE ABOVE) She’s feeding on his memories!
LORD: Not his memories, Doctor. His past. Every experience, every emotion. Every delight and sorrow. Every love and every loss...
DOCTOR: So that’s how you achieve sustenance. You’re parasites. Vampires! Forcing them to relive their lives, over and over again... just so that you have something to eat!
LORD: The price we pay for immortality. Innkeeper, do you wish the Lady Nyssa to stop?
DUDLEY: No. No. Please... I beg you, take it all... Please...
LADY: Join me, my Lord. Satiate your hunger. Consume this feast of purest regret!
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 71
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: LORD AND LADY FEED AND LAUGH HYSTERICALLY. AS THEY DO, MORE EXCERPTS OF SCENE 24 PLAY IN THE BACKGROUND. AND OVER IT:)
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) Max, don’t just stand there!
MAX: No, Doctor... You don’t understand..—
DOCTOR: Look at what they’re doing..! Do you really want to be the next course on the menu?
MAX: You don’t know what it’s like. If you had to live through all the moments you’d rather forget... all the humiliation and heartbreak... you’d want someone to take it away too.
DOCTOR: They’re not doing it for your benefit. To them you’re just a... source of nourishment! Come on, Max — run!
DOCTOR: (FX: AS THEY RUN, THE LORD AND LADY CONTINUE TO FEED — AND WE GO INTO ANOTHER FLASHBACK — SOUNDING LIKE THE PREVIOUS FLASHBACKS. )
DOCTOR: 43. RIVERBANK
JANE: I saw your face, when I told you the problem had gone away. You were pleased.
DUDLEY: I wasn’t.
JANE: Yes, you were. You didn’t really want it, you didn’t really want to marry me.
DUDLEY: It’s not like that — I want to do the right thing.
JANE: That’s just it. I don’t want you to be with me out of duty. Because you don’t really love me, Dudley and I don’t really love you. (BEAT) Our little problem didn’t go away.
JANE: (FX: GRADUALLY WE NOTICE TWO OTHER VOICES, ECHOING EACH LINE. NOT IN SYNCH, AND NOT THE SAME INTONATION. A MOCKING QUALITY. )
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 72
DOCTOR WHO: DUDLEY & LORD: What?
DOCTOR WHO: JANE & LADY:
DOCTOR WHO: I’m sorry for tricking you, but I had to know how you really felt. Don’t be angry. You can walk away now. Do what you do best. Walk away.
DOCTOR WHO: DUDLEY & LORD: You don’t understand, I love you —
DOCTOR WHO: JANE & LADY: Please, just leave me alone, I don’t want to see you any more...
DOCTOR WHO: DUDLEY & LORD: No!
DOCTOR WHO: JANE & LADY: Let go, you’re hurting me —
DUDLEY: One minute she was standing there, the next the edge just gave way — )
LADY: Oh, such exquisite remorse! Such delectable agony!
LORD: Now, Stargazer. It is your turn. Stargazer...?
LADY: He has gone... They have both gone!
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 73
DOCTOR WHO: 44. PIG BASE
NYSSA: So as far as you were concerned, I was one of these ghosts?
LIZZIE: Until we made physical contact... Another cup of tea? No? — But when we saw you, your presence was much more.. corporeal than any of the previous manifestations.
NYSSA: That’s what Max said about you.
LIZZIE: What?
NYSSA: That the ghosts were becoming more solid with each passing day.
LIZZIE: The link does seem to be getting stronger. It’s as if the village is slowly breaking through into our reality. That’s Geoff's theory, anyway. I think he got it off Buffy.
NYSSA: (CONSIDERING) Or maybe whatever caused Stockbridge to disappear in the first place is growing weaker.
LIZZIE: Wait a tic — did you say each passing day?
NYSSA: Yes. Max said the ghosts appeared at the same place, at the same time, every night —
LIZZIE: But the manifestations aren’t every day. They’re every couple of hours!
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 74
DOCTOR WHO: 45. INSIDE MANOR
LADY: Awake, innkeeper. Awake!
DUDLEY: (WAKING) I... thank you, My Lady. No more regret... no more guilt...
LORD: Your gratitude can wait. The Doctor and the stargazer have... absconded.
DUDLEY: Doctor Smith? Max — ?
LADY: The Doctor must be located. Instruct the villagers to search the grounds. At once!
LORD: And as for the stargazer.. his continued existence is no longer to be tolerated.
LORD: 46. PIG BASE
NYSSA: But that explains it.. why each day in the village felt like only a few hours...
LIZZIE: Because each day was only a few hours.
NYSSA: So these ghosts — manifestations — appear every hour or so?
LIZZIE: That’s right. As you can see from the wall chart — every one hour fifteen minutes, at present. The rate’s increasing, each time generating a larger psychic disturbance.
LIZZIE: NYSSA3: You can detect psychic disturbances?
LIZZIE: We’d hardly be the Psychic Investigation Group if we couldn’t. We have a (box of)-
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 75
LIZZIE: Hello, yeah? Geoffrey? .. What? Alright, alright, hold your horses, I’m on my way.
NYSSA: What is it?
LIZZIE: Another P.S.I. surge. The biggest one yet. Come on, ‘Nyssa’ — we’ve got work to do.
LIZZIE: 47. INSIDE MANOR CONSERVATORY
LIZZIE: (FX: FOUNTAIN TRICKLES. A DOOR IS UNBOLTED AND FLUNG OPEN. DOCTOR AND MAX RUSH IN.)
DOCTOR: Quick, Max, through here. Quick!
MAX: Oh blimey, my knees, my poor knees. (BEAT) We’re not leaving the manor?
DOCTOR: No. That’s exactly what they’d expect us to do. Instead I wanted another look at this.
MAX: What is it? Some sort of avant-garde sculpture?
DOCTOR: It’s what’s left of a hyperspatial warp core engine.
MAX: A what?
DOCTOR: Alien technology, far in advance of your own.
MAX: Oh, right. Actually, now you mention it, I thought it looked a bit Venusian.
DOCTOR: Yes, Max. Now, to sustain a four-dimensional bubble would require huge reserves of power... if I can divert some of that power into the synaptic feed...
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 76
MAX: Hey, look, that bit lit up! Fairy lights!
DOCTOR: Eureka! That’s the cardio-electric capacitor.. it indicates how — (REALISES) Oh dear.
MAX: Bad news?
DOCTOR: Extremely. Max, the reason why you’ve started seeing ghosts in Wells Wood... and why the days have been getting shorter... is because the time bubble’s collapsing.
MAX: Oh. (BEAT) What does that mean?
DOCTOR: Its structural integrity is breaking down. At first, allowing you a glimpse of the outside world. Then, becoming thin enough for someone to pass through. But ultimately...
MAX: Ultimately?
DOCTOR: What happens to all bubbles in the end? Pop!
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 77
DOCTOR WHO: 48. WELL’S WOOD
LIZZIE: Don’t just stand there gawping like a narna, move! (HALTS) Here we go, Wells Wood.
LIZZIE: (FX: THEY GET OUT. MACHINERY THROBBING. POWER CABLES. P.I.G. CHAT. )
NYSSA: What are you attempting to do with all this... ‘equipment’?
LIZZIE: Ah, well, it’s pretty complicated, I’m not sure you'd understand —
NYSSA: I think you’ll find I am more than capable of understanding anything you consider to be ‘complicated’.
LIZZIE: Alright, no need to get your knickers in a palaver. That box of tricks there, the one that looks like a big colander, is what we call a psychic amplifier.
NYSSA: It’s what you used to enter Stockbridge?
LIZZIE: Yes. Well guessed! This whole area’s basically a hotspot for psychic activity, a side-effect we’re guessing. By focusing that residual background energy, whenever there’s a manifestation... we can create a doorway, a sort of dimensional aperture.
NYSSA: Like forcing a lever into a fault line.
LIZZIE: You're the first person we’ve managed to pull through. You were lucky — the interface can be jolly unstable. Hazardous. That’s why we need to suit up.
NYSSA: You say it utilises psychic energy — you mean the power of thought?
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 78
LIZZIE: I know, I know, you have every right to be sceptical. But it’s not mumbo-jumbo, it’s all scientific fact. Ever since it was discovered in the nineteenth century, the existence of psychic energy has been an official secret.
NYSSA: It’s not that I doubt the science — I’ve seen similar technology before — I’m just wondering whether it might also be used to communicate.
LIZZIE: I’m sorry?
NYSSA: A psychic amplifier may also be used to boost an individual's latent psychic abilities.
LIZZIE: What, like telepathy?
NYSSA: To put it in terms you are capable of understanding, yes. We might be able to make contact with the Doctor!
LIZZIE: And do you happen to know of anyone with latent psychic abilities?
LIZZIE: NYSSA3: Of course. Me!
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 79
DOCTOR WHO: 49. MANOR HOUSE CONSERVATORY
DOCTOR: What do I have to do to make you work, you stupid (thing)...
DOCTOR: Ha! The old targeted-impact trick, never fails.
MAX: Hey, that’s a hologram... of the village!
DOCTOR: Yes. You can see, how it’s contained within the bubble. Rather like a snow globe.
MAX: Oh look, I can see my house! There’s even smoke coming out of the chimney!
DOCTOR: Yes, Max.
MAX: Doctor, what you said before, about the bubble going pop... what’1ll happen to us?
DOCTOR: This whole place will cease to exist. Everyone here will die. Permanently.
MAX: Oh lumme. (BEAT) How long do we have?
DOCTOR: Hard to say. The rate of deflation is gradual at the moment, but if it accelerates... then this ‘eternal summer’ of yours won’t be ‘eternal’ for very much longer.
MAX: Hey, what’s that wibbly thing?
DOCTOR: What — (OH NO) A breach in the time bubble’s surface...
MAX: A hole?
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 80
DOCTOR: Precisely. Somebody’s attempting to puncture the stasis field!
MAX: Puncture? Like sticking a drawing pin in a balloon?
DOCTOR: Precisely that sort of puncture. Interesting — the breach is located in... Well’s Wood!
MAX: Where the ghosts in spacesuits are!
DOCTOR: Where the psychic projections are, yes. They must be the ones behind it.
MAX: Doctor, don’t want to worry you, but should it be getting dark outside?
DOCTOR: Events are speeding up. Come on, Max, time we made a move.
MAX: Where?
DOCTOR: To Well’s Wood, of course.
MAX: What? To meet whoever’s trying to force their way in?
DOCTOR: More than that. We have to stop them!
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 81
DOCTOR WHO: 50. INSIDE MANOR
LADY: My Lord. The atmosphere of the village is shifting... changing... like there’s a thunderstorm approaching.
LORD: I sense it too. A chill breeze, rustling through the night.
LADY: The surging onrush of time, bringing destruction upon the village.
LORD: The eternal summer is over. Autumn is approaching...
LADY: It will be the end of us. We cannot endure without the stasis field.
LORD: Then we have no choice... we must beg the assistance of our
LORD: saviour...
LORD: LORD & LADY: Viridios!
LORD: 51. WELLS’ WOOD
NYSSA: Ready to engage power?
LIZZIE: This isn’t going to work, Nyssa. I’ll give you ten to one odds, it’ll fry your brain.
NYSSA: We have to try. Now!
LIZZIE: Switching on. Fingers crossed!
NYSSA: (IN PAIN) No... no...
LIZZIE: Okay, I’m switching (off) —
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 82
NYSSA: (IN PAIN) No, wait! Wait. I can see... I can the village green. The trees. The church. And a blue Police Box... and the Doctor and Max.. and a telephone, ringing...
NYSSA: Doctor. Can you hear me? Can you hear me? If you can hear me...
NYSSA: go to the woods tonight. Where I was taken. I’m coming back for you. I’ll show you the way through. Go to the woods, tonight —
LIZZIE: Oh my goodness... Nyssa? Are you alright?
NYSSA: I’m fine, but... there... there was something else...
LIZZIE: Something else?
NYSSA: Something alive. but incredibly ancient... and cold, so terribly cold. It felt like.. a living shadow..! I could hear its voice in my mind... and there was a word. A name!
LIZZIE: A name?
LIZZIE: NYSSA3: .Viridios.
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 83
DOCTOR WHO: 52. VILLAGE GREEN
MAX: Doctor... the sky... storm clouds! There’ve never been storm clouds over Stockbridge! Not since.. well, not since for as long as I can remember!
DOCTOR: The collapse is accelerating! Come on, Max, we have to (get) —
HAROLD: Yes, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Harold, Alice —
ALICE: What is it you ‘have’ to do?
MAX: Out of our way. Please, Mr Withers...
HAROLD: You never were part of Stockbridge, were you, Max? Never really fitted in.
MAX: Shut up, you rotten —
DUDLEY: The laughing stock of the village! Always gawping at the stars and chasing phantoms!
MAX: I said.. shut up —
ALICE: So lonely and pathetic. You never did find someone who could bear to be with you... But who would want to spend the rest of their life with an obese, ugly failure like you?
MAX: Leave me alone!
DUDLEY: The Lord and Lady have decreed you are no longer to be granted the gift of life...
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 84
DOCTOR: Max, ignore them. We have to go —
HAROLD: I don’t think so, Doctor. You’re not going anywhere... either of you.
HAROLD: 53. WELLS’ WOOD
LIZZIE: I don’t believe it. The P § I is still building. I’ve never seen anything like it, it’s nearly off the scale... alright, chaps! Environment suits on! That includes you, Nyssa.
LIZZIE: NYSSA3: Me?
LIZZIE: Here, your helmet, catch. Geoff, you all set with the psychic do-da? Okay — positions, everyone. Get ready. Five. Four. Three. Two. One...
LIZZIE: (FX: THE SOUND OF THE UNIVERSE RIPPING OPEN. A WHIRLWIND OF TIME. )
NYSSA: (VIA HELMET) The aperture — it’s opening!
LIZZIE: (VIA HELMET) Pretty spectacular, eh?
NYSSA: (VIA HELMET FROM NOW ON) It’s like.. a whirlpool in mid-air. And I can see... it’s night- time. Well’s Wood at night!
LIZZIE: (VIA HELMET FROM NOW ON) Okay, everyone — single file — after me...
LIZZIE: Passing through the interface. Whatever happens, Nyssa — stay with me —
NYSSA: I’m not sure I can (stand it) —
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 85
LIZZIE: There, dear. See. It’s fine once you’re in.
NYSSA: We’re still in Well’s Wood. But it’s..(dark) — look!
LIZZIE: What is it?
NYSSA: The Doctor. And Max. They’re here!
DOCTOR: (CALLS OUT) Hello there! Over here! I was wondering if you could help me?
LIZZIE: Nyssa, keep back, it’s not safe —
NYSSA: No. I’m going to get the Doctor.
DOCTOR: That’s right, you can hear me. Walk towards me... Nyssa, is that you? Nyssa!
NYSSA: Doctor. You need to make direct physical contact —
DOCTOR: What?
NYSSA: Take my hand, Doctor. There isn’t much time.
MAX: Doctor, I can’t let you do this —
NYSSA: (VIA SPACESUIT) Now, Doctor, now!
NYSSA: (FX: WITH A SUDDEN, UNIVERSE-RIPPING WHOOSH, WE’RE WRENCHED OUTSIDE THE BUBBLE. WE CAN HEAR THE EQUIPMENT POWERING DOWN. )
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 86
LIZZIE: I told you not to try anything! We were inside — and now we’re back to square one...!
NYSSA: Well, then we shall just have to try again, won’t we?
NYSSA: 54. VILLAGE GREEN
NYSSA: (FX: STORM RISING. A BOOM OF THUNDER. RAIN BEGINS TO POUR HEAVILY. )
DOCTOR: Look, I’m trying to help you!
DUDLEY: Help us? By abandoning us to join with the temporal intruders?
DOCTOR: Not to join them, no. To prevent them destroying this place!
HAROLD: You’re lying, Doctor. In Stockbridge we have life everlasting... a heaven on Earth!
DOCTOR: Is this your idea of heaven? Thunder and lightning and torrential rain! Your world is ending and you’re pointing a gun at the one man who can save you!
MAX: It’s no good, Doctor. They obey the Lord and Lady in all things...
DOCTOR: The storm — it’s getting worse! Max, find something to hold onto —
ALICE: Harold, help me. I can’t... the wind is too strong — Harold —
ALICE: (FX: HAROLD, ALICE AND DUDLEY SCREAMING, STRUGGLING IN THE WIND. )
DOCTOR: Come on, Max — this is our chance — Run!
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 87
DOCTOR WHO: 55. WELL’S WOOD.
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: PSYCHIC AMPLIFIER IS SHAKING WITH POWER. LOUDER THAN BEFORE. NYSSA IS OPERATING SWITCHES AND READING GAUGES )
NYSSA: More power. We’re nearly through!
LIZZIE: It’s only forty-five minutes since we last tried, there’s not enough residual —
NYSSA: No, look! It’s working — !
LIZZIE: I don’t believe it. You did it! You go girl! The aperture is opening —
NYSSA: And there they are... the Doctor and Max. Doctor!
DOCTOR: (DISTANT) Nyssa!
DOCTOR: NYSSA3: Quickly. Before the aperture closes —
DOCTOR: (FX: DOCTOR AND MAX PILE THROUGH, GASPING. THE APERTURE CLOSES WITH A SUCKING SOUND, CUTTING OFF THE SOUND OF THE STORM. )
MAX: What the dickens — it’s daylight — daylight! And there’s no storm. And we're...
DOCTOR: Yes, Max. I get the feeling we’re not in Stockbridge anymore...
NYSSA: Doctor, you’re safe. I’m so glad to see you, I (didn’t) — —
DOCTOR: Never mind that. Shut down that machine! Before you bring about the destruction of the entire planet!
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 88
DOCTOR WHO: 56. INSIDE MANOR
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: THE STORM CAN BE HEARD, OUTSIDE, THROUGH RATTLING WINDOWS. )
LORD: (FEARFUL) The Doctor and the stargazer have left the village.
LADY: The time bubble that has sustained us is fading. Eternity is coming to an end.
LORD: The end of Stockbridge. The end of us all.
LORD: (FX: VIRIDIOS SOUNDS ANCIENT. DEEP, SLOW, BOOMING AND YET HOARSE. )
VIRIDIOS: No, my children.
LADY: (BREATHLESS EXCITED RECOGNITION) Viridios...!
LORD: But if the time bubble has been ruptured — it is collapsing —
VIRIDIOS: There is another way. It can expand. To consume the whole wor 1d...
VIRIDIOS: END OF PART THREE CLIFFHANGER
DOCTOR WHO: THE ETERNAL SUMMER by Jonathan Morris (002) Page 89
